Award.AwardTitle: RAPID Collaborative research: Topographic change and cascading hazards following the November 13th Mw7.8 Kaikoura (New Zealand) earthquake
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Rapid Response Research (RAPID) project will examine the effects of the November 13, 2016, series of earthquakes in the Kaikoura region of New Zealand on faulting and landslide processes. The focus of the effort will be to develop a digital elevation model and time series for this event and conduct field work to evaluate the remote sensing products. The work will complement other urgent response efforts underway in New Zealand following the earthquakes. It will enhance international collaboration among scientists in the United States and New Zealand and meaningfully involve students in the scientific research process.

The 4D evolution of topography is critical for understanding faulting and landslide processes. For major events that deform and erode landscapes, such as earthquakes, we lack data at an event scale for understanding such processes because of the prohibitive cost of repeat land and airborne surveys. Existing high-resolution topographic surveys tend to be small in geographic extent, and thus the chance of catching an area before an event is rare and usually limited in scope. However, recent advances in high performance computing coupled with stereo-satellite imagery collection create the opportunity to provide regional scale data that can be processed for high-resolution topography. Such surveys can potentially be repeated with modest resources such that a topographic time series data can be created quickly and relatively inexpensively. Per contracts with the National Geospatial-Intelligence Agency and supercomputer centers, the PIs will gain access to the existing stereo imagery and super computer processing time needed to immediately develop and deliver a pre-event, high resolution digital elevation model to all researchers working on this event. This work will contribute to the understanding of landslide hazards after major earthquakes involving complex, multi-fault source mechanisms, and will be readily exportable to the scientific response of other earthquakes at other plate boundary settings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated topographic changes and hazards caused by the large 7.8 magnitude November 13th 2016 earthquake near Kaikoura, New Zealand. The remote sensing part of this effort focused on producing data sets suitable for measuring landscape changes in response to the event. Our aim was to use optical imagery from very high resolution sensors and digital models of the earth surface to look for landslides, fault rupture and any hazards triggered by the earthquake.

We used the NSF Bluewaters Petascale computing facility and local Rocky Mountain Advanced Computing Consortium high performance computing systems to produce 2-m resolution Digital Surface Models (DSM) for the entire region from before and after the Kaikoura event. The DSMs cover the area from about Christchurch northwards on the South Island of New Zealand and from about Palmerston, southwards on the North Island. The DSMs have been mosaiced and corrected to the best available ground control and have been manually quality checked through multiple iterations to provide the best available, consistent data sets. We derive ground control from NASA photon-counting spaceborne laser altimetry, ICESat-2. These altimeter returns are accurate in the vertical to much better than a meter. They ensure that the our DSMs are situated in the right place, at the right time. We processed about 2,200 satellite scene pairs from before the earthquake and 2,300 pairs from after the earthquake.

When differenced the DSMs highlight incredible detail. From the DSMs we can measure 3-dimensional fault motions and a large number of landslides with very high precision. The data also highlight landscape changes caused by urban growth and redevelopment, erosion, farming and forestry. Producing the data products required modification of some open-source software and involved a MSc student, a PhD student and the effort of a Postdoctoral scholar at CIRES, here at the University of Colorado, Boulder. We are waiting for permission to release the easily useable DSMs to the public (Spring 2020) which we anticipate can be used for a large number of subsequent studies.
